entries.title: ktl
entries.subtitle: High-performance multi-pod Kubernetes log tailer
entries.content:
ktl is the Kubernetes Swiss Army Knife.

Usage:
  ktl <command> [flags]

Flags:
  -K, --context string                    Name of the kubeconfig context to use
      --kube-log-level int                Kubernetes client-go verbosity (klog -v); at
                                          >=6 enables HTTP request/response tracing;
                                          can also set KTL_KUBE_LOG_LEVEL
  -k, --kubeconfig string                 Path to the kubeconfig file to use for CLI
                                          requests
      --log-level string                  Log level for ktl output (debug, info, warn,
                                          error) (default "info")
      --mirror-bus string                 Publish mirror payloads to a shared gRPC bus
                                          (ktl-agent MirrorService)
      --no-color                          Disable colored output
      --profile string                    Execution profile: dev, ci, secure, or
                                          remote (sets sensible defaults for supported
                                          commands) (default "dev")
      --remote-agent string               Forward ktl logs and deploy operations to a
                                          remote ktl-agent gRPC endpoint
      --remote-tls                        Use TLS for remote gRPC endpoints (also via
                                          KTL_REMOTE_TLS=1)
      --remote-tls-ca string              CA bundle PEM file for remote gRPC TLS (also
                                          via KTL_REMOTE_TLS_CA)
      --remote-tls-client-cert string     Client certificate PEM file for remote gRPC
                                          mTLS (also via KTL_REMOTE_TLS_CLIENT_CERT)
      --remote-tls-client-key string      Client private key PEM file for remote gRPC
                                          mTLS (also via KTL_REMOTE_TLS_CLIENT_KEY)
      --remote-tls-insecure-skip-verify   Skip TLS verification for remote gRPC (also
                                          via KTL_REMOTE_TLS_INSECURE_SKIP_VERIFY=1)
      --remote-tls-server-name string     Override remote gRPC TLS server name (also
                                          via KTL_REMOTE_TLS_SERVER_NAME)
      --remote-token string               Authentication token for remote gRPC
                                          endpoints (also via KTL_REMOTE_TOKEN)
examples:
# Tail checkout pods in prod-payments and highlight errors
	  ktl logs 'checkout-.*' --namespace prod-payments --highlight ERROR

# Initialize repo defaults
  ktl init

# Launch the interactive help UI
  ktl help --ui

# Preview a Helm upgrade
  ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release foo

# Revert a release to the last known-good revision
  ktl revert --release foo --namespace prod

# Apply chart changes
  ktl apply --chart ./chart --release foo --namespace prod

entries.title: ktl analyze
entries.subtitle: Analyze a Kubernetes pod for failures using heuristic or AI-powered diagnostics
entries.content:
Analyze a pod to determine why it is failing.
It fetches the pod status, recent events, and logs, then runs them through a diagnostic engine.

Examples:
  # Analyze a specific pod in the current namespace
  ktl analyze my-app-pod-123

  # Analyze a pod in a different namespace with AI enabled
  ktl analyze my-app-pod-123 -n prod --ai
  
  # Check for configuration drift (manual changes)
  ktl analyze my-app-pod-123 --drift
  
  # Estimate monthly cost
  ktl analyze my-app-pod-123 --cost
  
  # Profile resource usage vs requests
  ktl analyze my-app-pod-123 --profile
  
  # Audit RBAC permissions for the pod
  ktl analyze my-app-pod-123 --rbac
  
  # Automatically apply AI-suggested fixes (Use with caution)
  ktl analyze my-app-pod-123 --ai --fix
  
  # Analyze Cluster Health (Nodes, Global Events)
  ktl analyze --cluster

Usage:
  ktl analyze [POD_NAME] [flags]

Flags:
      --ai                  Use AI-powered analysis (requires API key)
      --cluster             Run cluster-wide health checks (nodes, system pods)
      --cost                Estimate monthly cost of the pod based on resource requests
      --drift               Check for configuration drift against
                            'kubectl.kubernetes.io/last-applied-configuration'
      --duration duration   Timeout for analysis (default 30s)
      --fix                 Automatically apply the suggested patch if available
      --model string        Override AI model (e.g., gpt-4-turbo, gpt-4o)
  -n, --namespace string    Kubernetes namespace (defaults to context)
      --profile             Profile resource usage (requires metrics-server)
      --provider string     Analysis provider: heuristic (default), openai, qwen,
                            deepseek, or mock (default "heuristic")
      --rbac                Audit RBAC permissions for the pod's ServiceAccount

entries.title: ktl apply
entries.subtitle: Render and apply a Helm chart using upgrade --install
entries.content:
Render and apply a Helm chart using upgrade --install

Usage:
  ktl apply [flags]

Flags:
      --atomic                        Rollback changes if the upgrade fails (default true)
      --capture string[="__auto__"]   Capture deploy events/logs/manifests to a SQLite
                                      database at this path
      --capture-tag stringArray       Tag the capture session (KEY=VALUE). Repeatable.
      --chart string                  Chart reference (path, repo/name, or OCI ref)
      --create-namespace              Create the release namespace if it does not exist
      --drift-guard                   Fail if live cluster resources drift from the
                                      last applied Helm release state
      --drift-guard-mode string       Drift guard mode: last-applied (compare to
                                      current Helm release) or desired (compare to
                                      newly rendered manifest) (default "last-applied")
      --dry-run                       Render the chart without applying it
  -n, --namespace string              Namespace for the Helm release (defaults to
                                      active context)
      --non-interactive               Fail instead of prompting (requires --yes)
      --plan-server                   Use server-side dry-run to classify replacements
                                      (slower; requires RBAC)
      --release string                Helm release name
      --require-verified string       Require a matching verify report (JSON) for this
                                      exact render before applying
      --secret-config string          Secrets provider config file (defaults to
                                      ~/.ktl/config.yaml and repo .ktl.yaml)
      --secret-provider string        Secret provider name for secret:// references
      --set stringArray               Set values on the command line (key=val)
      --set-file stringArray          Set values from files (key=path)
      --set-string stringArray        Set STRING values on the command line
      --timeout duration              Time to wait for any Kubernetes operation
                                      (default 5m0s)
      --ui string[=":8080"]           Serve the live deploy viewer at this address
                                      (e.g. :8080)
      --upgrade                       Only perform the upgrade path (skip install fallback)
  -f, --values strings                Values files to apply (can be repeated)
  -v, --verbose                       Enable verbose logging (equivalent to
                                      --log-level=debug)
      --version string                Chart version (default: latest)
      --wait                          Wait for resources to be ready (default true)
      --watch duration                After a successful deploy, stream logs/events
                                      for this long (e.g. 2m)
      --ws-listen string              Serve the raw deploy event stream over WebSocket
                                      at this address (e.g. :9086)
      --yes                           Alias for --auto-approve
examples:
# Apply a chart with prod values
  ktl apply --chart ./charts/web --release web-prod --namespace prod -f values/prod.yaml

# Deploy a chart
ktl apply --chart ./chart --release foo -n default

# Run the deploy viewer
ktl apply --chart ./chart --release foo -n default --ui

# Deploy with secret references
ktl apply --chart ./chart --release foo -n default --secret-provider local

# Deploy with Vault-backed secrets
ktl apply --chart ./chart --release foo -n default --secret-provider vault

entries.title: ktl apply plan
entries.subtitle: Preview Helm release changes without applying them
entries.content:
Render the chart, diff it against live cluster resources, and summarize the net creates/updates/deletes before running ktl apply.

Usage:
  ktl apply plan [flags]

Flags:
      --baseline string          Write plan JSON baseline to this path
      --chart string             Chart reference (path, repo/name, or OCI ref)
      --compare string           Plan artifact (path or URL) to embed for visualize
                                 comparisons
      --compare-exit             Exit non-zero when --compare-to detects regressions
                                 (default true)
      --compare-to string        Compare against a previous plan (path or URL) and
                                 report regressions
      --format string            Output format: text, json, yaml, or html (default "text")
      --include-crds             Render CRDs in addition to the main chart objects
  -n, --namespace string         Namespace for the Helm release (defaults to active
                                 context)
      --output string            Write the rendered plan to this path (HTML defaults
                                 to ./ktl-deploy-plan-<release>-<timestamp>.html)
      --release string           Helm release name
      --secret-config string     Secrets provider config file (defaults to
                                 ~/.ktl/config.yaml and repo .ktl.yaml)
      --secret-provider string   Secret provider name for secret:// references
      --set stringArray          Set values on the command line (key=val)
      --set-file stringArray     Set values from files (key=path)
      --set-string stringArray   Set STRING values on the command line
  -f, --values strings           Values files to apply (can be repeated)
      --version string           Chart version (default: latest)
      --visualize                Render the interactive visualization
      --visualize-explain        Add an Explain Diff tab in --visualize output
                                 (experimental)
examples:
# Preview a Helm upgrade
ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release foo -n default

# Render a shareable HTML visualization
ktl apply plan --visualize --chart ./chart --release foo -n default

# Preview with secret references
ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release foo -n default --secret-provider local

# Preview with Vault-backed secrets
ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release foo -n default --secret-provider vault

# Compare against a saved baseline
ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release foo -n default --compare-to ./plan.json

# Write a baseline snapshot
ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release foo -n default --baseline ./plan.json

entries.title: ktl build
entries.subtitle: Build container images with BuildKit
entries.content:
Build container images with BuildKit

Usage:
  ktl build CONTEXT [flags]

Flags:
      --allow-network                 Allow network egress when --hermetic is enabled
      --allow-unpinned-bases          Allow unpinned base images (FROM without @sha256
                                      digest) when --hermetic is enabled
      --attest-dir string             Write generated attestations (SBOM/provenance)
                                      to this directory as JSON files (implies --sbom
                                      and --provenance; requires OCI layout export)
      --authfile string               Path to the authentication file (Docker config.json)
      --build-arg stringArray         Add a build-time variable (KEY=VALUE)
      --builder string                BuildKit address (override with
                                      KTL_BUILDKIT_HOST) (default
                                      "unix:///run/user/501/buildkit/buildkitd.sock")
      --cache-dir string              Local cache directory for BuildKit metadata
                                      (default
                                      "/Users/antonvkrylov/Library/Caches/ktl/buildkit-cache")
      --cache-from stringArray        Cache import sources (comma-separated key=value
                                      pairs)
      --cache-intel                   Print a post-build cache summary (cache misses,
                                      slow steps, changed inputs) (default true)
      --cache-intel-format string     Cache intelligence output format: human or json
                                      (default "human")
      --cache-intel-output string     Write cache intelligence report to this path
                                      ('-' for stdout). Defaults to stderr in human mode.
      --cache-intel-top int           Max entries to show in the cache intelligence
                                      summary (default 10)
      --cache-to stringArray          Cache export destinations (comma-separated
                                      key=value pairs)
      --capture string[="__auto__"]   Capture build logs/events to a SQLite database
                                      at this path
      --capture-tag stringArray       Tag the capture session (KEY=VALUE). Repeatable.
      --compose-file stringArray      Compose file(s) to use when building compose projects
      --compose-parallelism int       Max parallel compose builds (default: NumCPU)
      --compose-profile stringArray   Compose profile(s) to enable
      --compose-project string        Override the compose project name
      --compose-service stringArray   Compose service(s) to build (default: all
                                      buildable services)
      --docker-context string         Docker context to use for buildx fallback
                                      (override with KTL_DOCKER_CONTEXT)
  -f, --file string                   Path to the Dockerfile (default: Dockerfile)
                                      (default "Dockerfile")
      --hermetic                      Enable hermetic/locked build mode (no network
                                      egress unless explicitly allowed; requires
                                      pinned base-image digests; records external fetches)
  -i, --interactive                   Drop into an interactive shell when a RUN step fails
      --interactive-shell string      Shell command to start when --interactive attaches
      --load                          Load the resulting image into the local
                                      container runtime (docker build --load)
      --locked                        Alias for --hermetic
      --logfile string                Log to file instead of stdout/stderr
      --mode string                   Build mode: auto, dockerfile, or compose
      --no-cache                      Disable BuildKit cache usage
      --oci                           Intent: export OCI layout and write attestations
                                      (implies --attest-dir when unset)
      --output string                 Build output mode: auto (default), tty (live
                                      dashboard), or logs (streaming) (default "auto")
      --platform strings              Target platforms (comma-separated values like
                                      linux/amd64)
      --policy string                 Policy bundle path or https URL to evaluate
                                      before/after build (OPA/Rego).
      --policy-mode string            Policy enforcement mode: enforce or warn
                                      (default "enforce")
      --policy-report string          Write a machine-readable policy report JSON to
                                      this path (defaults to
                                      --attest-dir/ktl-policy-report.json when
                                      --attest-dir is set)
      --provenance                    Generate a SLSA provenance attestation (in-toto)
                                      during the build
      --publish                       Intent: publish build (implies --push, and
                                      enables signing when combined with --sign)
      --push                          Push all tags to their registries after a
                                      successful build
  -q, --quiet                         Refrain from announcing build instructions and
                                      progress
      --rekor-url string              Override the Rekor transparency log URL used by
                                      cosign
      --remote string                 Remote builder address or 'auto' to provision
                                      ephemeral builder
      --remote-build string           Execute this build via a remote ktl-agent gRPC
                                      endpoint (host:port)
      --rm                            Remove intermediate containers after a
                                      successful build (default true)
      --sandbox                       Require executing the build inside the sandbox
                                      (fail if unavailable)
      --sandbox-bin string            Path to the sandbox runtime binary
      --sandbox-bind stringArray      Additional sandbox bind mounts (host:guest)
      --sandbox-bind-home             Bind-mount the current user's home directory
                                      into the sandbox (use with caution; prefer
                                      --authfile/--secret/--sandbox-bind)
      --sandbox-config string         Path to a sandbox runtime config file
      --sandbox-logs                  Stream sandbox runtime logs to stderr and the
                                      websocket mirror (when --ws-listen is set)
      --sandbox-probe-path string     Probe filesystem visibility before building by
                                      attempting to stat this host path
      --sandbox-workdir string        Working directory inside the sandbox (default:
                                      build context)
      --sbom                          Generate an SBOM attestation (in-toto) during
                                      the build
      --secret stringArray            Expose an environment variable as a BuildKit
                                      secret (NAME)
      --secrets string                Secret-leak guardrails: warn (default), block,
                                      or off (default "warn")
      --secrets-config string         Secrets rule config file or https URL
                                      (YAML/JSON). When unset, built-in defaults apply.
      --secrets-report string         Write a machine-readable secrets report JSON to
                                      this path (defaults to
                                      --attest-dir/ktl-secrets-report.json when
                                      --attest-dir is set)
      --secure                        Intent: secure build (implies
                                      hermetic+sandbox+attest+policy+secrets scan)
      --sign                          Sign pushed image tags with cosign after a
                                      successful build (requires --push)
      --sign-key string               cosign key reference for signing (e.g.
                                      awskms://..., gcpkms://..., azurekms://...)
  -t, --tag strings                   One or more image tags to apply to the result
      --tlog-upload string            Override cosign transparency log upload
                                      (true/false); default uses cosign's behavior
      --ws-listen string              Serve the raw BuildKit event stream over
                                      WebSocket at this address (e.g. :9085)
examples:
# Build the current directory
  ktl build .

# Enforce an OPA/Rego policy bundle (writes JSON evidence to dist/attest)
  ktl build . --attest-dir dist/attest --policy /path/to/policy --policy-mode enforce

# Auto-detect a compose project and build all services
  ktl build ./testdata/build/compose

# Build from a compose file directly and limit parallelism
  ktl build ./testdata/build/compose/docker-compose.yml --compose-parallelism 2

# Build with tags and push
  ktl build . -f Dockerfile -t ghcr.io/acme/app:latest --push

# Build an image from a directory
ktl build --context . --tag ghcr.io/acme/app:dev

# Share the build stream over WebSocket
ktl build --context . --ws-listen :9085

entries.title: ktl build login
entries.subtitle: Log in to a container registry
entries.content:
Log in to a container registry

Usage:
  ktl build login [SERVER] [flags]

Flags:
  -p, --password string   Registry password or token (prefer --password-stdin)
      --password-stdin    Read the password/token from stdin
  -u, --username string   Registry username
examples:
# Login to Docker Hub (interactive prompts if flags are omitted)
  ktl build login

# Login to GHCR using stdin (recommended)
  echo "$GITHUB_TOKEN" | ktl build login ghcr.io --username your-github-username --password-stdin

entries.title: ktl build logout
entries.subtitle: Log out of a container registry
entries.content:
Log out of a container registry

Usage:
  ktl build logout [SERVER]
examples:
# Logout of Docker Hub
  ktl build logout

# Logout of a specific registry
  ktl build logout ghcr.io

entries.title: ktl build sandbox
entries.subtitle: Sandbox tooling for ktl build
entries.content:
Sandbox tooling for ktl build

Usage:
  ktl build sandbox

entries.title: ktl build sandbox doctor
entries.subtitle: Diagnose nsjail sandbox readiness for ktl build
entries.content:
Diagnose nsjail sandbox readiness for ktl build

Usage:
  ktl build sandbox doctor [flags]

Flags:
      --context string   Build context directory to use when probing (default: cwd)

entries.title: ktl delete
entries.subtitle: Delete a Helm release and its resources
entries.content:
Delete a Helm release and its resources

Usage:
  ktl delete [flags]

Flags:
      --capture string[="__auto__"]   Capture destroy events/logs to a SQLite database
                                      at this path
      --capture-tag stringArray       Tag the capture session (KEY=VALUE). Repeatable.
      --disable-hooks                 Disable Helm hooks while destroying the release
      --dry-run                       Simulate destroy without removing resources
      --force                         Force uninstall even if Kubernetes resources are
                                      in a bad state
      --keep-history                  Retain release history (equivalent to helm
                                      uninstall --keep-history)
  -n, --namespace string              Namespace for the Helm release (defaults to
                                      active context)
      --non-interactive               Fail instead of prompting (requires --yes)
      --release string                Helm release name
      --timeout duration              How long to wait for resource deletions (default
                                      5m0s)
      --ui string[=":8080"]           Serve the destroy viewer at this address (e.g. :8080)
  -v, --verbose                       Enable verbose logging (equivalent to
                                      --log-level=debug)
      --wait                          Wait for resources to be deleted
      --ws-listen string              Serve the destroy event stream over WebSocket
                                      (e.g. :9087)
      --yes                           Alias for --auto-approve
examples:
# Delete a release but keep its history
  ktl delete --release web-prod --namespace prod --keep-history

# Delete a release
ktl delete --release foo -n default

# Run the destroy viewer
ktl delete --release foo -n default --ui

entries.title: ktl env
entries.subtitle: Show environment variables used by ktl
entries.content:
Show environment variables used by ktl

Usage:
  ktl env [flags]

Flags:
      --all               Include internal/legacy variables
      --category string   Filter to a category (case-insensitive)
      --format string     Output format: table, json, yaml (default "table")
      --match string      Filter by substring match against name/category/description
      --set               Show only variables with a non-empty value
examples:
# Show env var reference (machine-readable)
ktl env --format json

entries.title: ktl init
entries.subtitle: Initialize a repo with ktl defaults
entries.content:
Creates a repo-local .ktl.yaml with sane defaults and prints a short
getting-started checklist.

Usage:
  ktl init [path] [flags]

Flags:
      --apply-plan string         Apply a previously generated init plan (path or -
                                  for stdin)
      --dry-run                   Print the .ktl.yaml that would be written
      --force                     Overwrite an existing .ktl.yaml
      --gitignore                 Add the secrets file to .gitignore
      --gitignore-config          Also add .ktl.yaml to .gitignore
      --interactive               Run an interactive setup wizard
      --layout                    Create chart/ and values/ directories
      --merge                     Merge defaults into an existing .ktl.yaml
      --output string             Output format: text or json (default "text")
      --plan                      Output a replayable init plan as JSON (no changes
                                  applied)
      --plan-output string        Write plan JSON to a file instead of stdout
      --preset string             Opinionated init preset: dev, ci, prod
      --secrets-file string       Local secrets file path to reference in .ktl.yaml
                                  (default "./secrets.dev.yaml")
      --secrets-provider string   Secrets provider to scaffold (local, vault, aws,
                                  k8s) (default "local")
      --show-diff                 Show a diff when merging into an existing .ktl.yaml
      --stack                     Create a minimal stack.yaml in the repo root
      --template string           Apply a config template (name, path, or URL).
                                  Built-ins: platform, secure
      --validate                  Validate the generated config for common mistakes
                                  (default true)
      --values                    Create values/dev.yaml and values/prod.yaml
examples:
# Create a repo-local .ktl.yaml
ktl init

# Preview the config without writing
ktl init --dry-run

# Run the interactive wizard
ktl init --interactive

# Use an opinionated preset
ktl init --preset prod

# Apply a built-in template
ktl init --template platform

# Apply a template from a URL
ktl init --template https://example.com/ktl-init.yaml

# Merge defaults into an existing config
ktl init --merge

# Scaffold chart/ and values/ plus gitignore
ktl init --layout --gitignore

# Scaffold Vault-backed secrets
ktl init --secrets-provider vault

# Emit JSON for automation
ktl init --output json --dry-run

# Write a replayable init plan
ktl init --plan --plan-output .ktl/init-plan.json

# Apply a saved init plan
ktl init --apply-plan .ktl/init-plan.json

# Initialize another path
ktl init ./services/api

# Overwrite existing config
ktl init --force

entries.title: ktl lint
entries.subtitle: Examine a chart for possible issues
entries.content:
Examine a chart for possible issues

Usage:
  ktl lint [CHART]... [flags]

Flags:
      --kube-version string      Kubernetes version used for capabilities and
                                 deprecation checks
  -n, --namespace string         Namespace used for template rendering (default:
                                 current context)
      --quiet                    Print only warnings and errors
      --set stringArray          Set values on the command line (key=val)
      --set-file stringArray     Set values from files (key=path)
      --set-string stringArray   Set STRING values on the command line
      --skip-schema-validation   Disable JSON schema validation
      --strict                   Fail on lint warnings
  -f, --values strings           Values files to apply (can be repeated)
      --with-subcharts           Lint dependent charts under charts/
examples:
# Lint the current chart directory
  ktl lint

# Lint a specific chart with values
  ktl lint ./chart -f values/prod.yaml --strict

entries.title: ktl list
entries.subtitle: List Helm releases
entries.content:
List Helm releases

Usage:
  ktl list [flags]

Flags:
  -a, --all                  Show all releases without any filter applied
  -A, --all-namespaces       List releases across all namespaces
  -d, --date                 Sort by release date
      --deployed             Show deployed releases. If no other is specified, this
                             will be automatically enabled
      --failed               Show failed releases
  -f, --filter string        A regular expression (Perl compatible) to filter releases
                             by name
      --format string        Output format: table, json, or yaml (default "table")
  -m, --max int              Maximum number of releases to fetch (default 256)
  -n, --namespace string     Namespace scope for listing releases (defaults to active
                             context)
      --no-headers           Don't print headers when using the default output format
      --offset int           Next release index in the list, used to offset from start
      --pending              Show pending releases
  -r, --reverse              Reverse the sort order
  -l, --selector string      Label selector to filter releases by label query (works
                             only for secret/configmap backends)
  -q, --short                Output short (quiet) listing format
      --superseded           Show superseded releases
      --time-format string   Format time using Go time layout. Example: --time-format
                             "2006-01-02 15:04:05Z0700"
      --uninstalled          Show uninstalled releases (if uninstall --keep-history
                             was used)
      --uninstalling         Show releases that are currently being uninstalled
examples:
# List releases in the current namespace
  ktl list

# List across all namespaces
  ktl list -A

# Emit structured output
  ktl list --format json

entries.title: ktl logs
entries.subtitle: Tail Kubernetes pod logs
entries.content:
Stream pod logs with ktl's high-performance tailer. Accepts the same query/flag set as the legacy ktl entrypoint.

Usage:
  ktl logs [POD_QUERY] [flags]

Flags:
  -A, --all-namespaces                If present, tail across all namespaces
                                      (overrides --namespace)
      --capture string[="__auto__"]   Capture logs to a SQLite database at this path
      --capture-tag stringArray       Tag the capture session (KEY=VALUE). Repeatable.
  -m, --color string                  Force set color output. 'auto': colorize if tty
                                      attached, 'always': always colorize, 'never':
                                      never colorize (default "auto")
      --condition stringArray         Filter pods by condition, e.g. ready=false
      --config string                 Path to stack.yaml (used with --deps)
  -c, --container strings             Regex filter for container names (repeat to OR
                                      multiple)
      --container-colors strings      Comma-separated SGR color codes used to color
                                      container names
      --deploy-mode string            When using deploy/<name>, pick which replica
                                      sets to follow: active, stable, canary,
                                      stable+canary (default "active")
      --deploy-pin string             Deprecated: use --deploy-mode. When using
                                      deploy/<name>, pin replica sets in the selection
                                      (comma-separated: stable,canary)
      --deploy-prune-grace duration   When using deploy/<name>, keep tailed pods for
                                      this long after they fall out of the selected
                                      replica sets (default 15s)
      --deploy-refresh duration       When using deploy/<name>, refresh deployment
                                      selection at this interval (fallback when watch
                                      is unavailable) (default 2s)
      --deps                          Include logs from dependencies defined in stack.yaml
  -d, --diff-container                Display different colors for different containers
  -e, --events                        Include Kubernetes events that match the pod selector
  -O, --events-only                   Only stream matching events (implies --events)
  -x, --exclude string                Regex to skip log lines that match
  -C, --exclude-container strings     Regex for container names to exclude
      --exclude-pod strings           Regex for pod names to exclude
      --field-selector string         Field selector to filter pods (e.g.
                                      spec.nodeName=kind-control-plane)
      --filter string                 Filter JSON logs by key=value (e.g. level=error,
                                      status=500)
  -f, --follow                        Follow log output (default true)
  -H, --highlight stringArray         Log lines to highlight (regular expression)
  -j, --json                          Emit raw JSON log lines without decoration
  -n, --namespace strings             Kubernetes namespace to use. Defaults to the
                                      context namespace; repeat or use comma-separated
                                      values for multiple.
      --no-follow                     Alias for --follow=false
  -P, --no-prefix                     Disable default prefix (overrides template to
                                      just message)
      --node-log strings              Specific node/system log files (relative to
                                      /var/log) to stream via the kubelet proxy;
                                      repeat for multiple
      --node-log-all                  Stream node logs from every node instead of only
                                      those hosting matched pods
      --node-log-only                 Suppress pod logs and stream only node/system logs
      --node-logs                     Also stream node/system logs (defaults to
                                      kubelet.log) from nodes hosting matched pods
      --only-log-lines                Print only the log message body (no timestamps
                                      or prefixes)
  -o, --output string                 Specify predefined template: default, raw, json,
                                      extjson, ppextjson (default "default")
      --plain                         Shorthand for --only-log-lines and --no-prefix
  -g, --pod-colors strings            Comma-separated SGR color codes used to color
                                      pod names (e.g. "91,92,93")
  -l, --selector string               Label selector to filter pods
  -s, --since string[="0s"]           Return logs newer than a relative duration like
                                      5s, 2m, or 3h
      --stdin                         Read log lines from STDIN instead of Kubernetes
  -t, --tail int[=10]                 Number of historic log lines to show, -1 for all
                                      available (default 10)
  -p, --template string               Go template for log lines; available fields:
                                      Timestamp, Namespace, PodName, ContainerName,
                                      Message, Raw (default "[{{.Timestamp}}]
                                      {{.PodDisplay}} {{.ContainerTag}} {{.Message}}")
      --template-file string          Path to a Go template file for log output
  -F, --timestamp-format string       Go time format string for timestamps (use
                                      "youtube" for H:MM:SS) (default "youtube")
  -T, --timestamps                    Show timestamps in output (default true)
      --timezone string               IANA timezone name used when rendering
                                      timestamps (e.g. Asia/Tokyo)
      --ws-listen string              Expose a raw WebSocket log feed at this address
                                      (e.g. :9090)
examples:
# Tail pods matching a regex in a namespace
ktl logs 'checkout-.*' -n prod-payments

# Highlight errors
ktl logs 'checkout-.*' -n prod-payments --highlight ERROR

entries.title: ktl revert
entries.subtitle: Revert a Helm release to a previous revision
entries.content:
Revert a Helm release to a previous revision

Usage:
  ktl revert [flags]

Flags:
      --dry-run            Show the target revision and exit without changing the cluster
  -n, --namespace string   Namespace for the Helm release (defaults to active context)
      --non-interactive    Fail instead of prompting (requires --yes)
      --release string     Helm release name
      --revision int       Target revision to revert to (default: last known-good)
      --timeout duration   How long to wait for the rollback (default 5m0s)
  -v, --verbose            Enable verbose logging (equivalent to --log-level=debug)
      --wait               Wait for resources to become ready (default true)
      --yes                Auto-approve confirmation prompts
examples:
# Revert a release to the last known-good revision
ktl revert --release foo -n default

entries.title: ktl secrets
entries.subtitle: Inspect and validate deploy-time secret providers
entries.content:
Inspect and validate deploy-time secret providers

Usage:
  ktl secrets
examples:
# Validate a secret reference
ktl secrets test --secret-provider vault --ref secret://vault/app/db#password

# List secrets under a provider prefix
ktl secrets list --secret-provider local --path app --format json

# Discover secret refs across the repo
ktl secrets discover --scope repo

# Discover secret refs for a chart
ktl secrets discover --scope chart --chart ./chart --values values/dev.yaml

# Discover secret refs for a stack
ktl secrets discover --scope stack --config ./stacks/prod

entries.title: ktl secrets discover

      --chart-version string     Chart version (scope=chart)

      --include-unused           Include configured but unused secret providers
      --output string            Output format: table or json (default "table")
      --root string              Repo root (scope=repo) or stack root when --config is

      --scope string             Discovery scope: repo, chart, or stack (default "repo")
      --secret-config string     Secrets provider config file (defaults to

      --secret-provider string   Default secret provider name for secret:// references
      --set strings              Set values on the command line (scope=chart)
      --set-file strings         Set values from files on the command line (scope=chart)
      --set-string strings       Set string values on the command line (scope=chart)
      --values strings           Values file(s) to include (scope=chart)

entries.title: ktl stack
entries.subtitle: Compile and orchestrate many Helm releases as a dependency graph
entries.content:
ktl stack discovers stack.yaml/release.yaml, compiles them with inheritance into a DAG, and runs ktl apply/delete per release.

Minimal-flags workflow: put defaults into stack.yaml `cli:` and/or KTL_STACK_* env vars (see docs/stack-cli-defaults.md). Run `ktl env --match stack` to discover environment overrides.

Usage:
  ktl stack

Flags:
      --config string            Path to stack root directory or stack.yaml/release.yaml
      --plan-only                Compile and print the plan, but do not execute
      --profile string           Profile overlay name (defaults to
                                 stack.yaml.defaultProfile when present)
      --secret-config string     Secrets provider config file (defaults to
                                 ~/.ktl/config.yaml and repo .ktl.yaml)
      --secret-provider string   Secret provider name for secret:// references
examples:
# Plan the stack (default: read-only, like `ktl stack plan`)
ktl stack --config ./stacks/prod

# Restrict selection via environment defaults
KTL_STACK_TAG=critical KTL_STACK_CLUSTER=prod-us ktl stack --config ./stacks/prod

# Emit a machine-readable plan for tooling
ktl stack --config ./stacks/prod --output json

entries.title: ktl stack apply
entries.subtitle: Apply the selected stack releases in DAG order
entries.content:
Apply the selected stack releases in DAG order

Usage:
  ktl stack apply [flags]

Flags:
      --from-bundle string        Run from a sealed plan bundle (.tgz)
      --helm-logs string[="on"]   Helm log capture + TTY rendering mode: off|on|all
                                  (default off)
      --replan                    Recompute the plan from current config when resuming
      --resume                    Resume the most recent run (uses its frozen plan
                                  unless --replan is set)
      --run-id string             With --resume: resume a specific run ID; otherwise:
                                  set the new run ID
      --sealed-dir string         Run from a sealed plan/bundle directory (expects
                                  plan.json + inputs.tar.gz)
      --yes                       Skip confirmation prompts
examples:
# Apply the selected releases (DAG order)
ktl stack apply --config ./stacks/prod --yes

# Resume the most recent run (uses stored frozen plan unless --replan is set)
ktl stack apply --config ./stacks/prod --resume --yes

# Enable manifest diffs (defaulted via env)
KTL_STACK_APPLY_DIFF=1 ktl stack apply --config ./stacks/prod --yes

# Apply with secret references
ktl stack apply --config ./stacks/prod --secret-provider vault --yes

entries.title: ktl stack audit
entries.subtitle: Show who/what/when for a stack run (sqlite-backed)
entries.content:
Show who/what/when for a stack run (sqlite-backed)

Usage:
  ktl stack audit [flags]

Flags:
      --events int       How many events to include in json/html output (0 uses
                         default, -1 means all) (default 1000)
      --include-events   Include stored events in json/html output (default true)
      --include-plan     Include the stored run plan in json/html output (default true)
      --output string    Output format: table|json|html (default "table")
      --run-id string    Run ID (stored in .ktl/stack/state.sqlite); defaults to most
                         recent
      --verify           Verify event chain and run digest (default true)
examples:
# Show audit table for the most recent run
ktl stack audit --config ./stacks/prod

# Export a shareable HTML report
ktl stack audit --config ./stacks/prod --output html > stack-audit.html

entries.title: ktl stack delete
entries.subtitle: Delete the selected stack releases in reverse DAG order
entries.content:
Delete the selected stack releases in reverse DAG order

Usage:
  ktl stack delete [flags]

Flags:
      --from-bundle string        Run from a sealed plan bundle (.tgz)
      --helm-logs string[="on"]   Helm log capture + TTY rendering mode: off|on|all
                                  (default off)
      --replan                    Recompute the plan from current config when resuming
      --resume                    Resume the most recent run (uses its frozen plan
                                  unless --replan is set)
      --run-id string             With --resume: resume a specific run ID; otherwise:
                                  set the new run ID
      --sealed-dir string         Run from a sealed plan/bundle directory (expects

entries.title: ktl stack rerun-failed
entries.subtitle: Resume the most recent run and schedule only failed nodes
entries.content:
Resume the most recent run and schedule only failed nodes

Usage:
  ktl stack rerun-failed [flags]

Flags:
      --allow-drift               Allow rerun even when inputs changed since the plan
                                  was written (unsafe)
      --concurrency int           Maximum number of concurrent releases to run (default 1)
      --lock                      Acquire a stack state lock for this run (default true)
      --lock-owner string         Lock owner string (defaults to user@host:pid)
      --lock-ttl duration         How long before the lock is considered stale
                                  (default 30m0s)
      --progressive-concurrency   Start at 1 worker, then ramp up/down based on
                                  successes/failures
      --retry int                 Maximum attempts per release (includes the initial
                                  attempt) (default 1)
      --run-id string             Resume a specific run ID (stored in
                                  .ktl/stack/state.sqlite)
      --takeover                  Take over the stack state lock if held (unsafe)
      --yes                       Skip confirmation prompts
examples:
# Resume the most recent run and schedule only failed nodes
ktl stack rerun-failed --config ./stacks/prod --yes

entries.title: ktl tunnel
entries.subtitle: Smart, resilient port-forwarding for multiple services
entries.content:
Auto-detects ports and manages multiple resilient tunnels.
Examples:
  ktl tunnel app --share         # Listen on 0.0.0.0 (share with LAN)
  ktl tunnel app --deps          # Also tunnel to app's dependencies (from stack.yaml)
  ktl tunnel app --hosts         # Add 'app.local' to /etc/hosts (requires sudo)
  ktl tunnel db --exec "npm run migrate"  # Run script when tunnel is ready
  ktl tunnel db --env-from deployment/app --exec "go run ." # Run local app with remote env
  ktl tunnel app --web           # Start web dashboard

Usage:
  ktl tunnel [SERVICE_OR_POD...] [flags]

Flags:
      --config string      Path to stack.yaml (used with --deps)
      --deps               Recursively tunnel to dependencies defined in stack.yaml
      --env-from string    Fetch environment variables from workload (e.g. deployment/app)
      --error-rate float   Inject artificial errors (0.0 - 1.0)
      --exec string        Command to run when all tunnels are active
      --hosts              Update /etc/hosts with .local aliases (requires sudo)
      --latency duration   Inject artificial latency (e.g. 500ms)
  -n, --namespace string   Kubernetes namespace
      --share              Listen on all interfaces (0.0.0.0) to share with LAN
      --web                Start web dashboard on port 4545

entries.title: ktl tunnel intercept
entries.subtitle: Intercept traffic from a remote service to local machine
entries.content:
Redirects traffic destined for a remote Kubernetes Service to your local machine.
It works by:
1. Deploying a reverse-tunnel agent (SSH server).
2. Updating the target Service's selector to point to the agent.
3. Tunneling traffic back to your local port.

When you exit (Ctrl+C), the Service selector is restored.

Example:
  # Intercept traffic for service 'backend' and send to localhost:8080
  ktl tunnel intercept backend 8080

Usage:
  ktl tunnel intercept [TARGET_SERVICE] [LOCAL_PORT] [flags]

Flags:
  -n, --namespace string   Kubernetes namespace

entries.title: ktl tunnel list
entries.subtitle: List saved tunnel profiles
entries.content:
List saved tunnel profiles

Usage:
  ktl tunnel list

entries.title: ktl tunnel reverse
entries.subtitle: Expose a local port to the cluster (Reverse Tunnel)
entries.content:
Creates a reverse tunnel so the cluster can access a local service.
It deploys a temporary SSH server in the cluster, creates a Service pointing to it,
and sets up a reverse SSH tunnel from your machine.

Example:
  # Expose local port 3000 as service 'my-webhook' on port 80
  ktl tunnel reverse my-webhook 3000

Usage:
  ktl tunnel reverse [SERVICE_NAME] [LOCAL_PORT] [flags]

Flags:
  -n, --namespace string   Kubernetes namespace

entries.title: ktl tunnel save
entries.subtitle: Save a tunnel profile
entries.content:
Save a tunnel profile

Usage:
  ktl tunnel save NAME TARGET...

entries.title: ktl tunnel share
entries.subtitle: Expose a local port to the internet via Cluster Ingress
entries.content:
Creates a reverse tunnel to the cluster and exposes it via a temporary Ingress resource.
This effectively makes your local service accessible via a public URL (if the cluster has an Ingress Controller).

Example:
  ktl tunnel share 3000 --host my-app.dev.example.com

Usage:
  ktl tunnel share [LOCAL_PORT] [flags]

Flags:
      --host string        Public hostname for the ingress (e.g. my-app.example.com)
  -n, --namespace string   Kubernetes namespace

entries.title: ktl tunnel sync
entries.subtitle: Live file synchronization to a pod (Hot Reload)
entries.content:
Watches a local directory and synchronizes changes to a remote pod directory in real-time.
Requires 'tar' to be available in the remote container.

Example:
  ktl tunnel sync ./src my-app:/app/src

Usage:
  ktl tunnel sync [LOCAL_DIR] [POD_NAME:REMOTE_DIR] [flags]

Flags:
  -n, --namespace string   Kubernetes namespace

entries.title: ktl up
entries.subtitle: Start a development workspace defined in ktl.yaml
entries.content:
Reads a 'ktl.yaml' file in the current directory and starts all defined tunnels and log streams.
This allows you to define your development environment as code.

Example ktl.yaml:
  tunnels:
    - target: redis:6379
      local: 6379
    - target: postgres:5432
      local: 5432
  logs:
    - query: my-app
    - query: worker

Usage:
  ktl up

entries.title: ktl version

entries.content:
Print the ktl client version information

examples:
# Print version information
ktl version

entries.title: ktl wait
entries.subtitle: Wait for a pod to be ready AND match a log pattern
entries.content:
Wait for a pod to satisfy conditions that are harder to check with kubectl wait.
Useful for CI/CD pipelines where you need to wait for an app to be "business ready" (e.g. "Server started on port 8080").

Example:
  ktl wait my-app --for-log "Server started" --timeout 60s

Usage:
  ktl wait [POD_NAME_PATTERN] [flags]

Flags:
      --for-log string     Wait until this string appears in the logs
  -n, --namespace string   Kubernetes namespace
      --timeout duration   Timeout for the wait (default 1m0s)

entries.title: Architecture
entries.subtitle: Repo layout and core packages
entries.content:
# KTL Architecture (Current)

This repo is a single-module Go CLI with an optional companion agent.

## Layout
- `cmd/ktl`: end-user CLI (Cobra) and CLI-only helpers.
- `cmd/ktl-agent`: gRPC agent used by `--remote-agent` / `--mirror-bus`.
- `internal/*`: non-exported libraries used by the CLI/agent (tailing, deploy/apply, UI mirroring, BuildKit workflows, config/feature flags).
- `pkg/*`: reusable non-`internal` packages (BuildKit/Compose/registry helpers and generated API stubs under `pkg/api/ktl/api/v1`).
- `testdata/*`: fixtures and golden files.

## Main Commands (wired today)
- `init`
- `build`
- `apply` (and `apply plan`)
- `delete`
- `stack`
- `revert`
- `list`
- `lint`
- `logs`
- `env`
- `secrets`
- `version`

The root command wiring lives in `cmd/ktl/main.go`.

## Internal Package Map (Purpose, Key Types, Invariants)

This section is intentionally short and repetitive: AI agents do best with a stable map of where responsibilities live, which symbols are entrypoints, and what must not change.

### `internal/config`

- Purpose: shared CLI/config-layer options (flags + config binding + validation).
- Key types: `Options` (`AddFlags`, `BindFlags`, `Validate`).
- Invariants: CLI packages should call into `Options` rather than re-parsing env/config ad-hoc.

### `internal/featureflags`

- Purpose: register and resolve feature flags consistently.
- Key types: `Definition`, `Flags` (`Enabled`, `EnabledNames`), `Name`, `Stage`.
- Invariants: flag names stay kebab-cased; toggles flow via context/config/env (dont introduce new toggle mechanisms).

### `internal/logging`

- Purpose: structured logging configuration and shared logger helpers.
- Key entrypoints: `internal/logging/logger.go` (logger construction/config).
- Invariants: avoid global loggers; pass loggers/context through call chains.

### `internal/grpcutil`

- Purpose: gRPC dial/wiring helpers for local/remote agent connections.
- Key entrypoints: `internal/grpcutil/dial.go`.
- Invariants: keep connection/security defaults centralized here (avoid duplicating dial options in commands).

### `internal/api/convert`

- Purpose: translate between internal runtime structs and protobuf API types (`pkg/api/ktl/api/v1`).
- Key types: `BuildConfig`, `DeployApplyConfig`, `DeployDestroyConfig`.
- Invariants: conversion is one-way boundary glue; dont leak protobuf types into core packages.

### `internal/kube`

- Purpose: Kubernetes client helpers used by tailing/deploy.
- Key types: `Client` (`Exec`).
- Invariants: Kubernetes API calls accept `context.Context` and are cancellable.

### `internal/tailer`

- Purpose: stream logs (pods/nodes) and feed observers (terminal, UI).
- Key types: `Tailer` (`Run`), `LogRecord`, `LogObserver`, `Option`.
- Invariants: tailing is streaming and cancellation-driven; observers must tolerate bursts and duplicates.

### `internal/deploy`

- Purpose: Helm apply/delete orchestration and progress/event streaming to observers (TTY + UI).
- Key types: `InstallOptions`/`InstallResult`, `TemplateOptions`/`TemplateResult`, `StreamBroadcaster`, `StreamEvent`, `ResourceTracker`, `ResourceStatus`.
- Invariants: observers are optional and must not block the core deploy loop; events should remain stable for UI consumers.

### `internal/secretstore`

- Purpose: resolve `secret://` references in deploy-time values using pluggable providers.
- Key types: `Resolver`, `Config`, `Provider`.
- Invariants: never log secret values; audit references only.

### `internal/ui`

- Purpose: terminal UX primitives (deploy console, spinner).
- Key types: `DeployConsole` + `DeployConsoleOptions`, `DeployMetadata`.
- Invariants: UI code should consume observer/event interfaces rather than reaching into core packages.

### `internal/caststream`

- Purpose: UI mirror server (HTTP/WebSocket) that streams logs/build/deploy events to the browser.
- Key types: `Server` (`Run`, `ObserveLog`, `HandleDeployEvent`), `Mode`, `Option`.
- Invariants: server is a pure observer of streaming events; it must not own core business logic.

### `internal/mirrorbus`

- Purpose: publish log streams onto the gRPC mirror bus for remote viewers.
- Key types: `Publisher` (`ObserveLog`, `Close`).
- Invariants: publisher must remain non-blocking and safe to close at any point.

### `internal/dockerconfig`

- Purpose: Docker auth/config resolution used during builds and remote operations.
- Key entrypoints: `internal/dockerconfig/dockerconfig.go`.
- Invariants: never log credentials; keep file paths/config parsing centralized.

### `internal/csvutil` / `internal/castutil`

- Purpose: small utilities for CSV/cast formatting used across workflows.
- Invariants: keep these packages dependency-light and free of side effects.

### `internal/workflows/buildsvc`

- Purpose: BuildKit-based image build workflow orchestration (including sandbox support and progress observers).
- Key types: `service.Run(ctx, opts) (*Result, error)`, `Result`, `Dependencies`, `Streams`, `BuildMode`.
- Invariants: build is streaming + cancellable; sandbox policy is selected/configured centrally (dont fork policy logic in commands).
- Notes: progress observers emit cache diagnostics and a post-build cache intelligence report (input diffs, cache key/graph diffs, slow steps, and OCI layer size rollups when an OCI layout is produced).

### `internal/agent`

- Purpose: gRPC server implementation for the remote agent.
- Key types: `Server` (`Run`), per-service handlers (`LogServer`, `BuildServer`, `DeployServer`, `MirrorServer`).
- Invariants: agent handlers forward events via existing observer interfaces (dont duplicate deploy/build logic inside the agent).

## Agent-Facing Docs

- Golden paths + validation commands: `docs/agent-playbook.md`
- UI design system (HTML/CSS surfaces): `DESIGN.md`
- gRPC agent API: `docs/grpc-agent.md`
- Generated package dependency map: `docs/deps.md` (refresh with `make deps`)

entries.title: Config atlas
entries.subtitle: stack.yaml, verify YAML, sandbox profiles
entries.content:
# Configuration atlas

Practical, copy/paste-friendly examples for the configs that power `ktl`.

This is intentionally biased toward what do I put in the file? rather than exhaustive schema docs.

## ktl config (`.ktl.yaml` / `~/.ktl/config.yaml`)

Use the repo or global config file to set deploy-time secret providers or build defaults.

```yaml
# .ktl.yaml
build:
  profile: ci

secrets:
  defaultProvider: local
  providers:
    local:
      type: file
      path: ./secrets.dev.yaml

  # Example Vault provider
  # vault:
  #   type: vault
  #   address: https://vault.example.com
  #   authMethod: approle
  #   authMount: approle
  #   roleId: 00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000
  #   secretId: s.0000000000000000000000
  #   # kubernetesRole: ktl
  #   # kubernetesTokenPath: /var/run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/token
  #   # awsRole: ktl
  #   # awsRegion: us-east-1
  #   # awsHeaderValue: vault.example.com
  #   mount: secret
  #   kvVersion: 2
  #   key: value
```

### Vault auth method examples

AppRole:
```yaml
secrets:
  defaultProvider: vault
  providers:
    vault:
      type: vault
      address: https://vault.example.com
      authMethod: approle
      authMount: approle
      roleId: 00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000
      secretId: s.0000000000000000000000
      mount: secret
      kvVersion: 2
```

Kubernetes:
```yaml
secrets:
  defaultProvider: vault
  providers:
    vault:
      type: vault
      address: https://vault.example.com
      authMethod: kubernetes
      authMount: kubernetes
      kubernetesRole: ktl
      kubernetesTokenPath: /var/run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/token
      mount: secret
      kvVersion: 2
```

AWS IAM:
```yaml
secrets:
  defaultProvider: vault
  providers:
    vault:
      type: vault
      address: https://vault.example.com
      authMethod: aws
      authMount: aws
      awsRole: ktl
      awsRegion: us-east-1
      awsHeaderValue: vault.example.com
      mount: secret
      kvVersion: 2
```

## `stack.yaml` (minimal, with CLI defaults)

This is the minimal-flags stack workflow: keep defaults in `stack.yaml` under `cli:` and override with `KTL_STACK_*` only when needed.

```yaml
# stack.yaml
name: prod

# Defaults applied to all releases unless overridden.
defaults:
  namespace: platform

  # Optional Kubernetes-only post-apply health gates (see docs/stack-verify.md).
  verify:
    enabled: true
    failOnWarnings: true
    warnOnly: false
    eventsWindow: 15m
    timeout: 2m
    denyReasons: ["FailedMount", "FailedScheduling", "ImagePullBackOff", "ErrImagePull", "BackOff"]

  # Runner behavior (how releases are scheduled/executed).
  runner:
    concurrency: 6
    progressiveConcurrency: true

# CLI defaults for `ktl stack ...` so you can run with fewer flags.
# Precedence: flags > KTL_STACK_* env > stack.yaml cli > built-in defaults.
cli:
  output: table
  inferDeps: true
  inferConfigRefs: false
  selector:
    clusters: ["prod-us"]
    tags: ["critical"]
    includeDeps: true
    includeDependents: false
    allowMissingDeps: false
  apply:
    dryRun: false
    diff: true
  delete:
    confirmThreshold: 50
  resume:
    allowDrift: false
    rerunFailed: false

releases:
  - name: api
    chart: ./charts/app
    values: ["./values/api.yaml"]
    tags: ["critical", "team-payments"]

  - name: worker
    chart: ./charts/app
    values: ["./values/worker.yaml"]
    tags: ["team-payments"]
    # Override verify settings per release.
    verify:
      enabled: false
```

Notes:
- `ktl stack` is read-only by default (prints a plan); use `ktl stack apply` / `ktl stack delete` to execute.
- Profile overlays: use `profiles.<name>.cli` and `profiles.<name>.defaults` to override per environment (dev/stage/prod).
- For CLI schema details, see `docs/stack-cli-defaults.md`.

## `verify` YAML (chart render + live checks)

`verify` supports multiple targets. Two common ones:

Tip: generate a starter config with `verify init chart|namespace` and then customize it.

### Verify a chart render (no cluster access)

```yaml
# verify-chart-render.yaml
version: v1

target:
  kind: chart
  chart:
    chart: ./chart
    release: foo
    namespace: default
    values:
      - values.yaml
    set:
      - image.tag=dev
    useCluster: false
    includeCRDs: false

verify:
  mode: block        # warn|block
  failOn: high       # low|medium|high|critical
  selectors:
    include:
      namespaces: ["default"]
    exclude:
      kinds: ["ConfigMap"]
  baseline:
    write: ./baseline.json   # write a JSON baseline snapshot
    read: ./baseline.json    # compare against baseline on next run
    exitOnDelta: true        # fail when new/changed findings appear

output:
  format: table      # table|json|sarif|html|md
  report: "-"        # "-" stdout, or a path
```

Tip: CLI overrides are available for baselines:
```bash
verify verify.yaml --baseline ./baseline.json
verify verify.yaml --compare-to ./baseline.json
```

### Verify a live namespace

```yaml
# verify-namespace.yaml
version: v1

target:
  kind: namespace
  namespace: default

kube:
  context: my-context

verify:
  mode: warn
  failOn: high

output:
  format: table
  report: "-"
```

## Sandbox profiles (`sandbox/*.cfg`)

Sandbox policies live under `sandbox/` and are selected via `KTL_SANDBOX_CONFIG` (or `--sandbox-config`).

Example (CI-like policy):

```bash
export KTL_SANDBOX_CONFIG="$(pwd)/sandbox/linux-ci.cfg"
ktl build --context . --tag ghcr.io/acme/app:dev
```

What matters most in a policy:
- `name`/`hostname` so logs clearly identify the profile in use.
- `clone_new*` namespace settings (user/pid/cgroup isolation vs compatibility).
- `rlimit_*` ceilings (tmpfs sizes, file size, nproc, etc.).
- `mount` blocks (what is visible in the sandbox).

For threat model + guidance, see `docs/sandbox-security.md`.

entries.content:
Registered feature flags

Enable per invocation with `ktl --feature <name>` (repeatable/comma-separated), via config (`feature: ["<name>"]`), or env vars `KTL_FEATURE_<FLAG>`.

- deploy-plan-html-v3 (experimental, default off)
  Env: KTL_FEATURE_DEPLOY_PLAN_HTML_V3
  Switch ktl apply plan visualize output to the v3 UI components.

entries.title: Recipes
entries.subtitle: Golden paths (copy/paste workflows)
entries.content:
# Recipes (golden paths)

Copy/paste workflows that cover the common happy paths for `ktl`.

## Zero-conf onboarding

```bash
# Initialize repo defaults and detect your kubecontext
ktl init

# Run the interactive setup wizard
ktl init --interactive

# Scaffold chart/ and values/ plus gitignore entries
ktl init --layout --gitignore

# Use an opinionated preset
ktl init --preset prod

# Apply an init template (built-in or URL)
ktl init --template platform
ktl init --template https://example.com/ktl-init.yaml

# Scaffold a Vault secrets provider
ktl init --secrets-provider vault

# Preview the config without writing
ktl init --dry-run

# Generate a replayable init plan
ktl init --plan --plan-output .ktl/init-plan.json

# Apply a saved init plan
ktl init --apply-plan .ktl/init-plan.json

# Launch the interactive help UI
ktl help --ui
```

## Apply a chart (with and without the UI)

```bash
# Preview what will change
ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release foo -n default

# Deploy
ktl apply --chart ./chart --release foo -n default

# Deploy with the viewer UI
ktl apply --chart ./chart --release foo -n default --ui
```

## 5-minute demo (public chart)

Do this:
```bash
helm repo add bitnami https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami
helm repo update

ktl apply plan --chart bitnami/nginx --release demo-nginx -n default --visualize
ktl apply --chart bitnami/nginx --release demo-nginx -n default --yes
ktl delete --release demo-nginx -n default --yes
```

## Recommended `.ktl.yaml` layout

Do this:
```yaml
build:
  profile: ci

secrets:
  defaultProvider: local
  providers:
    local:
      type: file
      path: ./secrets.dev.yaml
```

## Apply with secret references

```bash
# Define providers in .ktl.yaml (or pass --secret-config)
cat > .ktl.yaml <<'YAML'
secrets:
  defaultProvider: local
  providers:
    local:
      type: file
      path: ./secrets.dev.yaml
YAML

# Use secret:// references in values
cat > values.dev.yaml <<'YAML'
db:
  password: secret://local/db/password
YAML

ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release foo -n default -f values.dev.yaml --secret-provider local
ktl apply --chart ./chart --release foo -n default -f values.dev.yaml --secret-provider local
ktl stack apply --config ./stacks/prod --secret-provider local --yes
```

## Vault-backed secrets

```bash
cat > .ktl.yaml <<'YAML'
secrets:
  defaultProvider: vault
  providers:
    vault:
      type: vault
      address: https://vault.example.com
      authMethod: approle
      authMount: approle
      roleId: 00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000
      secretId: s.0000000000000000000000
      mount: secret
      kvVersion: 2
      key: value
      # kubernetesRole: ktl
      # kubernetesTokenPath: /var/run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/token
      # awsRole: ktl
      # awsRegion: us-east-1
      # awsHeaderValue: vault.example.com
YAML

cat > values.dev.yaml <<'YAML'
db:
  password: secret://vault/app/db#password
YAML

ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release foo -n default -f values.dev.yaml --secret-provider vault
ktl apply --chart ./chart --release foo -n default -f values.dev.yaml --secret-provider vault
ktl stack apply --config ./stacks/prod --secret-provider vault --yes
```

Inspect providers and references:
```bash
ktl secrets test --secret-provider vault --ref secret://vault/app/db#password
ktl secrets list --secret-provider vault --path app --format json
```

Minimal CLI workflow (sanity check before apply):
```bash
ktl secrets test --secret-provider vault --ref secret://vault/app/db#password
ktl secrets list --secret-provider vault --path app
```

## Regression-proof plans

Do this:
```bash
ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release foo -n default --baseline ./plan.json
ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release foo -n default --compare-to ./plan.json
```

## Regression-proof verify

Do this:
```bash
verify verify.yaml --baseline ./baseline.json
verify verify.yaml --compare-to ./baseline.json
```

## Share an `apply plan` visualization

```bash
ktl apply plan --visualize --chart ./chart --release foo -n default
```

## Stack: minimal-flags workflow (plan  apply)

```bash
export KTL_STACK_ROOT=./stacks/prod

# Read-only plan (default `ktl stack` behaves like `ktl stack plan`)
ktl stack

# Execute (DAG order)
ktl stack apply --yes
```

## Stack: resume / rerun failed

```bash
export KTL_STACK_ROOT=./stacks/prod

# Resume the most recent run (frozen plan unless --replan is set)
ktl stack apply --resume --yes

# Convenience: resume and schedule only failed nodes
ktl stack rerun-failed --yes
```

## Stack: inspect runs

```bash
export KTL_STACK_ROOT=./stacks/prod

ktl stack runs --limit 50
ktl stack status --follow
ktl stack audit --output html > stack-audit.html
```

## Build: share the build stream over WebSocket

```bash
ktl build --context . --tag ghcr.io/acme/app:dev --ws-listen :9085
```

## Verify: validate a chart render in CI

```bash
cat > verify-chart-render.yaml <<'YAML'
version: v1

target:
  kind: chart
  chart:
    chart: ./chart
    release: foo
    namespace: default
    useCluster: false

verify:
  mode: block
  failOn: high

output:
  format: table
  report: "-"
YAML

verify verify-chart-render.yaml

# Package a chart then verify the archive
package ./chart --output dist/chart.sqlite
package --verify dist/chart.sqlite
```

entries.title: Troubleshooting
entries.subtitle: Symptom  why  what to run next
entries.content:
# Troubleshooting

Symptom  why it happens  what to run next.

## Helm apply/plan issues

### Symptom: release not found / unexpected install vs upgrade

Why:
- The release name/namespace is different than you expect, or the cluster context is wrong.

What to run:
```bash
ktl list -n <namespace>
ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release <name> -n <namespace>
```

Next steps:
- Confirm `--kubeconfig` / `--context` and `-n` match the target cluster/namespace.
- Prefer `ktl apply plan` first when uncertain.

### Symptom: diff looks wrong / resources missing

Why:
- Values/`--set` are not what you think, or templating differs across environments.

What to run:
```bash
ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release <name> -n <namespace>
```

Next steps:
- Check which values files are passed and whether any `KTL_*` env overrides apply.

## RBAC / Kubernetes auth

### Symptom: forbidden / cannot list  at the cluster scope

Why:
- The current kube context lacks permissions for the requested operation.

What to run:
```bash
kubectl auth can-i --list -n <namespace>
ktl apply plan --chart ./chart --release <name> -n <namespace>
```

Next steps:
- Use the correct `--context`/`--kubeconfig`.
- If you need read-only discovery first, start with `ktl apply plan` or `ktl stack` (read-only).

## Timeouts / stuck rollouts

### Symptom: apply waits forever / readiness never becomes true

Why:
- The underlying workload is failing to become Ready (image pull, scheduling, probes, etc.).

What to run:
```bash
ktl logs '<workload|pod-regex>' -n <namespace> --highlight ERROR
kubectl get pods -n <namespace>
kubectl describe pod -n <namespace> <pod>
```

Next steps:
- Look for Warning events like `FailedScheduling`, `ImagePullBackOff`, `ErrImagePull`.
- If using `ktl stack`, follow the run stream:
  - `ktl stack status --follow`

## Stack selection surprises

### Symptom: selection matched 0 releases

Why:
- Selector defaults/overrides are too strict.

What to run:
```bash
ktl env --match stack
ktl stack --config <stack-root>
```

Next steps:
- Temporarily remove filters (`KTL_STACK_TAG`, `KTL_STACK_RELEASE`, `KTL_STACK_FROM_PATH`, `KTL_STACK_GIT_RANGE`).
- Use `ktl stack explain <name>` to understand why a release is/was selected.

## Build sandbox / BuildKit issues

### Symptom: sandbox denies a path / missing mount

Why:
- The sandbox policy is stricter than your build needs (missing bind mounts, tmpfs too small, etc.).

What to run:
```bash
export KTL_SANDBOX_CONFIG="$(pwd)/sandbox/linux-ci.cfg"
ktl build --context . --tag ghcr.io/acme/app:dev --sandbox-logs
```

Next steps:
- Inspect `[sandbox]` diagnostics.
- If you need tighter security, start from `sandbox/linux-strict.cfg` and add only the required mounts.
